official-title.#text:
Honoring Thomas Jennings of New York City as the first African-American to be granted a patent by
			 the United States.

cosponsor.#text: Ms. Eddie Bernice Johnson of Texas
Mr. Sean Patrick Maloney of New York

cosponsor.#tail: ) submitted the following resolution; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
United States
			 Patent and Trademark Office

text.#text: honors Thomas Jennings as the first African-American to be granted a patent by the

commends Thomas Jennings for his economic contributions to the United States through use of the
			 patent system; and

acknowledges that Thomas Jennings’ inventive contributions encourage Americans to continue a legacy
			 of innovation in the fields of science, technoloy, engineering, and math.

Whereas Thomas Jennings was born a free African-American in New York City in 1791 and became a
			 successful tailor with a shop on Church Street in New York City;

term.#tail: , which was the precursor to dry cleaning;

text.#text: Whereas Thomas Jennings invented a cleaning process called

Whereas, on March 3, 1821, Thomas Jennings became the first African-American to be granted a patent
			 by the United States for his cleaning process;

Whereas, before the Civil War, patent laws made it significantly hard, if not impossible, for
			 slaves to hold a patent, but Thomas Jennings was able to obtain a patent
			 because of his free status; and

Whereas Thomas Jennings utilized the earnings from his invention and business to help advance civil
			 rights for African-Americans and to advocate for the abolition of slavery:
			 Now, therefore, be it

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}title.#text: 113 HRES 514 IH: Honoring Thomas Jennings of New York City as the first African-American to be granted a patent by the United States.
